Award.AwardTitle: National CyberWatch: Cybersecurity Education Solutions for the Nation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
CyberWatch has been funded as an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Regional Center of Excellence since 2005 (NSF Award Nos. 0501828 and 0902747) and has expanded its membership to 94 colleges in 29 states. With this award, the center transitions to an even broader scope as an ATE National Center of Excellence.

The mission of CyberWatch is "to advance cybersecurity education by leading collaborative efforts to strengthen the national cybersecurity workforce." The center is building a culture of collaboration among colleges and universities to:

* promote the growth of cybersecurity education programs nationally, especially in community colleges;
* build program and faculty capacity by sharing replicable models of excellence;
* promote the cybersecurity profession through a national dissemination program;
* strengthen student capacity and expand pathways to cybersecurity careers; and
* support research on cybersecurity education.

By promoting "models of excellence," CyberWatch is expanding high-quality cybersecurity programs at community colleges around the nation. The center is mentoring colleges to achieve the Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education - 2 Year (CAE2Y) designation; increasing students' awareness of cybersecurity careers and their participation in cybersecurity competitions at the K-12 and college levels; growing the number of faculty able to teach cybersecurity topics; assisting with curriculum development at all levels; expanding the knowledge base of what works (and what does not) in cybersecurity education at all levels; and continuing effective dissemination mechanisms, including the center's Web sites, newsletters, reports, conference presentations, and workshops and institutes, all of which advertise the center's services to a broad community.

As a national center, CyberWatch is leading the effort to bring cybersecurity education at community colleges to the forefront of the national dialogue, thereby helping employers across the nation to meet a critical workforce need.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SUMMARY

National CyberWatch Center achieved significant and far-reaching impact on cybersecurity education, workforce development, and research in community colleges and beyond, under NSF Award 1204533. This is attested by the following significant accomplishments and advances:

  • Successful shift from regional to national center
  • Growing visibility and network
  • Continued voice of community colleges in national cybersecurity education and workforce development efforts
  • Support at the state level
  • New website, collateral materials, and Brand Guideline
  • Dissemination and outreach (e.g., press/media articles, TV interviews, Webinar Series, conference presentations/panels); integrated social media and communication platforms (e.g., regular communications to members via monthly e-Newsletter and e-news blasts; increased media release pickups)
  • New initiatives: National CyberWatch Center Library; National CyberWatch Center Digital Press; FREE monthly Webinar Series; Community College Cyber Summit (3CS)
  • National Cybersecurity Student Association launch to include: website, marketing materials, and sponsorship package
  • Continued world-class cybersecurity competitions: Mid-Atlantic Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition (MACCDC) and National Cyber League (NCL)
  • National Security Agency (NSA)/Dept. of Homeland Security (DHS) National Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense Two-Year (CAE CD-2Y) leadership role and support
  • Expanded collaboration within the NSF Advanced Technological Education (ATE) community
  • National curriculum efforts: Content strategy; Knowledge Units vs. Mapping Report: Centers of Academic Excellence (CAE) Knowledge Units (KUs) to the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities (KSAs); National CyberWatch Center Collaborative Curriculum Taskforce: Study of the National Cybersecurity Workforce Framework to Academic Courses Mapping; Mapping of Academic Courses to National Cybersecurity Workforce Framework; new degree & certificate programs and technical courses
  • National K-12 efforts: Increased media coverage and publications; Cool Careers in Cybersecurity for Girls National Tour; National CyberSTEM Educator Academy Training; National dissemination of CyberSTEM Summer camps and after-school programs, and new focus on research in this area; First annual National K-12 Cybersecurity Conference
  • Digital Press: two published Resources Guides: A Guide for Mapping Courses to Knowledge Units (KUs); Preparing for the Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition (CCDC): A Guide for New Teams and Recommendations for Experienced Players
  • Prince George's Community College was the first community college in the country to re-designate as a National Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense Two-Year, under the new criteria
  • Published 5 e-Books: Ethical Hacking & Systems Defense; Information Security Fundamentals; Introduction to Scripting; Linux Fundamentals; Networking Fundamentals

Given that community college cybersecurity education was in its infancy only a decade ago, National CyberWatch and its predecessor CyberWatch centers, have created many useful resources and have reached an impressive audience, while at the same time increasing the quantity and quality of the Information Security technician workforce.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The National CyberWatch Center advanced the role of community colleges in cybersecurity education nationally by developing and promulgating models of impact regarding curriculum, labor workforce needs, extra-curricular programs, Centers of Academic Excellence expansion, transfer pathways, professional certifications, accreditations, and standards. National CyberWatch contributed to the development of intellectual capital in community college cybersecurity education through its involvement in national conversations. National CyberWatch continued to build the intellectual foundation for advances in America’s ability to train an effective and qualified workforce to protect its systems, infrastructure, and people.

BROADER IMPACT

National CyberWatch extended the already broad outreach of its work under successive NSF grants as a regional Center. The National CyberWatch goals and objectives addressing program development, curricula, Centers of Academic Excellence expansion, collaborations and interactions with academic community, government and industry, and involvement with national boards and groups were designed to significantly impact diverse communities on the national level. National CyberWatch’s resources, such as curriculum materials, online learning modules, Resource Guides, and collaborations will reached an ever-wider audience among community colleges and universities, other educators at all levels, industry, and governmental entities. As a result, many more students, faculty, colleges/universities, and employers will be vested and versed in cybersecurity principles and practices, and our nation will be safer because of it.


Last Modified: 12/05/2017
Modified by: Casey W O'brien
